# The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the parent company to The Ritz-Carlton Hotel brand. For
other uses, see [Ritz (disambiguation)](/wiki/Ritz_\(disambiguation\) "Ritz
\(disambiguation\)").

**The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company, LLC** is an American company that operates
the [luxury hotel](/wiki/Hotel#Luxury "Hotel") chain known as **The Ritz-
Carlton.** The company has 91 [luxury
hotels](/wiki/Conference_and_resort_hotels "Conference and resort hotels") and
[resorts](/wiki/Resort "Resort") in 30 countries and territories.[1]

The current company was founded in 1983, when the previous owners sold the
Ritz-Carlton [brand name](/wiki/Brand_name "Brand name") and the Ritz-Carlton
hotel in [Boston](/wiki/Boston "Boston"), [Massachusetts](/wiki/Massachusetts
"Massachusetts").[1] The brand was subsequently expanded to other locations.
The company is today a subsidiary of [Marriott
International](/wiki/Marriott_International "Marriott International").[1]

## Predecessor company[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Ritz-
Carlton_Hotel_Company&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Predecessor
company")]

### Ritz, Carlton and Ritz-Carlton in
Europe[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Ritz-
Carlton_Hotel_Company&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Ritz, Carlton and
Ritz-Carlton in Europe")]

The story of The Ritz-Carlton begins with [Swiss](/wiki/Swiss "Swiss")
hotelier [César Ritz](/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Ritz "César Ritz"), who was well known
in the hotel industry as the "king of hoteliers and hotelier to kings"
redefined luxury accommodation in Europe with his management of [The
Ritz](/wiki/H%C3%B4tel_Ritz_Paris "Hôtel Ritz Paris") in Paris and the
[Carlton Hotel](/wiki/Carlton_Hotel,_London "Carlton Hotel, London") in
London, among others. He and the renowned chef from his hotels, [Auguste
Escoffier](/wiki/Auguste_Escoffier "Auguste Escoffier"), opened [a la
carte](/wiki/A_la_carte "A la carte") restaurants known as _Ritz-Carlton_ on
board the [Hamburg-Amerika Line](/wiki/Hamburg-Amerika_Line "Hamburg-Amerika
Line") ocean liners [SS _Amerika_](/wiki/USS_America_\(ID-3006\) "USS America
\(ID-3006\)") in 1905 and [SS _Imperator_](/wiki/SS_Imperator "SS Imperator")
in 1913.[2] The restaurants on those ships ceased operating in 1914 with the
outbreak of [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"). Although Ritz died
in 1918, his wife Marie continued the tradition of opening hotels in his
name.[3]

### The Ritz-Carlton in North America[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Ritz-
Carlton_Hotel_Company&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: The Ritz-Carlton in
North America")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/HK_The_Ritz-
Carlton_hotel_b.JPG/220px-HK_The_Ritz-
Carlton_hotel_b.JPG)](/wiki/File:HK_The_Ritz-Carlton_hotel_b.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:HK_The_Ritz-Carlton_hotel_b.JPG "Enlarge")

The Ritz-Carlton logo at the former Hong Kong property

The Ritz-Carlton Investing Company was established by Albert Keller, who
bought and franchised the name in the United States. The first [Ritz-Carlton
Hotel](/wiki/Ritz-Carlton_Hotel_\(New_York\) "Ritz-Carlton Hotel \(New
York\)") in the U.S. opened in New York City in 1911.[4] It was located at
46th Street and [Madison Avenue](/wiki/Madison_Avenue_\(Manhattan\) "Madison
Avenue \(Manhattan\)"). [Louis Diat](/wiki/Louis_Diat "Louis Diat") ran the
kitchens and invented [Vichyssoise](/wiki/Vichyssoise "Vichyssoise") there.[5]
In 1911, the Ritz company announced its intention to expand to Philadelphia
and Atlantic City.[6] The Ritz-Carlton Philadelphia followed in 1913[7] at
Broad & Walnut streets,[8] designed by Horace Trumbauer and [Warren &
Wetmore](/wiki/Warren_%26_Wetmore "Warren & Wetmore").[9] The [Ritz-Carlton
Montreal](/wiki/Ritz-Carlton_Montreal "Ritz-Carlton Montreal") opened in 1912,
not owned by Keller as it was located in Canada. Keller's [Ritz-Carlton
Atlantic City](/wiki/Ritz-Carlton_Atlantic_City "Ritz-Carlton Atlantic City")
opened in 1921.[10]

### The Boston hotel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Ritz-
Carlton_Hotel_Company&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: The Boston hotel")]

In October 1926, 29-year-old Edward N. Wyner bought a third-acre parcel at the
corner of Arlington and Newbury streets and formed a partnership called The
Ritz-Arlington Trust with his father, George, and business associate, John S.
Slater.

The trust sold $2.1 million of bonds to finance the construction of an
apartment building to be called the Mayflower. The 18-story, 201-foot (61 m)
brick building, designed by Strickland, Blodget & Law Architects, was far
taller than anything else along Newbury Street at the time. Construction had
started on the second floor when Wyner was persuaded by then-Mayor [James
Michael Curley](/wiki/James_Michael_Curley "James Michael Curley") to make the
Mayflower a world-class, 300-room Ritz-Carlton Hotel, which opened May 19,
1927. Room rates were $5 to $15 per night; $40 per night for suites.

After a hugely successful opening, the stock market crash of 1929 and ensuing
Depression brought financial difficulties. The Wyner family funded the hotel’s
operating losses during the early 1930s, although the interest on the bonds
went unpaid. Still in 1933, when only 30 guests were registered in the hotel,
Wyner turned on the lights in every guest room to give the appearance the
hotel was full.

### Decline of the first Ritz-Carlton
chain[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Ritz-
Carlton_Hotel_Company&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Decline of the
first Ritz-Carlton chain")]

The Philadelphia location was converted to an office building after only a few
years in operation. The Atlantic City hotel was sold to Schine Hotels in the
late 1940s, and later [Sheraton Hotels](/wiki/Sheraton_Hotels "Sheraton
Hotels") in 1959.[10] The New York hotel was demolished in 1951, leaving only
the Boston location.[11]

Edward Wyner died of a heart attack on December 5, 1961. His six sons tried to
continue operation of the Boston hotel, but were unable to overcome
difficulties, and decided to sell.

### The Blakeley years: 1964–1983[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Ritz-
Carlton_Hotel_Company&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: The Blakeley years:
1964–1983")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Ritz_Carlton_in_Washington%2C_D.C..JPG/220px-
Ritz_Carlton_in_Washington%2C_D.C..JPG)](/wiki/File:Ritz_Carlton_in_Washington,_D.C..JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Ritz_Carlton_in_Washington,_D.C..JPG "Enlarge")

The Ritz-Carlton, [Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington,
D.C.")

The unpaid interest on the bonds dissuaded many from trying to buy the hotel.
But Cabot, Cabot & Forbes principal Gerald F. Blakeley Jr. was interested.
After more than a year of legal work, [Hale and
Dorr](/wiki/Wilmer_Cutler_Pickering_Hale_and_Dorr "Wilmer Cutler Pickering
Hale and Dorr") succeeded at clearing the bond obligations, and in October
1964 Blakeley and associates Paul Hellmuth and Charles Spaulding acquired the
Ritz-Carlton Boston for $3.8 million.

“Out of the 20 years I owned it, it made money three years. The other years it
broke even, but from a public relations standpoint for CC&F, it was a
tremendous asset,” said Blakeley, who completed a 19-story Ritz-Carlton luxury
[condominium](/wiki/Condominium "Condominium") complex on land adjacent to the
hotel in 1981.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In the late 1960s Blakeley obtained the rights to the Ritz-Carlton name in
North America (with the exception of Montreal and New York). In June 1978,
Blakeley was awarded the rights and privileges of the Ritz-Carlton trademark
in the United States and was given a US Service Mark Registration.

In the 1970s, the Ritz-Carlton name was licensed to the builders of a new
hotel in Chicago. [The Ritz-Carlton Chicago](/wiki/The_Ritz-Carlton_Chicago
"The Ritz-Carlton Chicago") opened in 1975 in a tower atop Water Tower Place.
It joined the [Four Seasons Hotels &
Resorts](/wiki/Four_Seasons_Hotels_%26_Resorts "Four Seasons Hotels &
Resorts") chain in 1977, as there was no Ritz-Carlton chain at the time.
Confusingly, it remained part of Four Seasons for decades, marketed as "The
Ritz-Carlton Chicago (A Four Seasons Hotel)". It had no association with the
modern Ritz-Carlton chain, though it used the name and the iconic logo. The
property was sold in 2013 and left Four Seasons, joining the modern Ritz-
Carlton chain as a franchise on August 1, 2015.[12]

In 1982, Blakely licensed the name to hotelier John B. Coleman for two hotels
he was renovating, [The Fairfax](/wiki/The_Fairfax_at_Embassy_Row "The Fairfax
at Embassy Row") in Washington, D.C. and the Navarro in New York City. Coleman
renamed them The Ritz-Carlton Washington D.C. and The Ritz-Carlton New York in
April 1982. Coleman paid Blakely a fee of 1.5 percent of each hotel's annual
gross revenue for use of the name.[13] The two hotels eventually joined the
modern chain that would be founded a few years later.

## Current company[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Ritz-
Carlton_Hotel_Company&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Current company")]

In August 1983, Blakeley sold The Ritz-Carlton Boston and the US trademark for
$75.5 million to developer William B. Johnson,[14] who assembled a four-person
development team in Atlanta, headed by hotelier Horst Schulze,[15] to create
The Ritz-Carlton concept and established The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Co.

In 1988, Johnson subsequently obtained the exclusive rights to The Ritz-
Carlton name throughout the world except for the 210-room Hotel-Ritz Paris,
The Ritz-Carlton at Water Tower Place in Chicago, and The Ritz-Carlton in
Montreal.

### The corporate years: 1983–1999[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Ritz-
Carlton_Hotel_Company&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: The corporate
years: 1983–1999")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Wolfsburg7.jpg/220px-
Wolfsburg7.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wolfsburg7.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wolfsburg7.jpg "Enlarge")

The Ritz-Carlton at the [Autostadt](/wiki/Autostadt "Autostadt") in
[Wolfsburg](/wiki/Wolfsburg "Wolfsburg"), [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany"):
completed in 2000, it was the first hotel of the company to open in Europe.

From 1951 to 1975, The Ritz-Carlton Boston had been one of only two Ritz-
Carlton hotels in the US. The other was the independently owned [Ritz-Carlton
Atlantic City](/wiki/Ritz-Carlton_Atlantic_City "Ritz-Carlton Atlantic City")
which had since been converted to condominiums. Johnson's company paid the
Atlantic City establishment to abandon its name and rename itself The Ritz
Condominiums.[10]

Johnson would later enlarge the company from just the Boston property to 30
hotels worldwide in just 10 years. He obtained financing to do so from
Manufacturers Hanover Trust of New York in 1983 in the amount of $85 million
secured by The Ritz-Carlton Boston. This loan was refinanced in 1989 by
Manhattan Tops USA of New York for $136.5 million and again in 1994 by
Sumitomo Bank of Japan. By 1996, this mortgage was in default and the interest
and penalties brought the total debt to $214.8 million.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] By
splitting this mortgage note into three parts, Sumitomo Bank was able to
unbundle The Ritz-Carlton Boston from the trademark rights to The Ritz-Carlton
brand worldwide.

Blackstone Real Estate Acquisitions of New York bought The Ritz-Carlton Boston
at auction for $75 million in February 1998. A month later, [Marriott
International](/wiki/Marriott_International "Marriott International") of
[Bethesda, Maryland](/wiki/Bethesda,_Maryland "Bethesda, Maryland"), acquired
the[_[where?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Naming_conventions_\(geographic_names\)
"Wikipedia:Naming conventions \(geographic names\)")_]hotel from Blackstone
for $100 million. Marriott, which franchises and manages Marriott’s 325,000
rooms, then bought The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Co. and rights to The Ritz-Carlton
name worldwide from W.B. Johnson for $290 million in a two-part transaction
completed in 1998.

### Disposal of the historic Boston
property[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Ritz-
Carlton_Hotel_Company&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Disposal of the
historic Boston property")]

In 1998, Christopher Jeffries, founding partner of Millennium Partners,
obtained The Ritz-Carlton franchises from Marriott for four hotel properties
under construction: two in Washington, one in [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), and one in [Atlanta,
Georgia](/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta"). In addition, Jeffries was searching for a
brand affiliation for the new 155-room hotel and 270-luxury condominiums he
was constructing as part of Boston’s 1,800,000-square-foot (170,000 m2)
Millennium Place, a mixed-use complex on lower Washington Street. Due to
noncompetition clauses, the only way he could obtain a second Ritz-Carlton
flag in Boston was to own the existing Ritz-Carlton.

Millennium Partners acquired the original Ritz-Carlton Boston for $122 million
(though it had sold for just $75 million less than two years prior) and spent
$50 million for renovations. Marriott agreed to allow The Ritz-Carlton
affiliation for the condominium complex, known as The Residences at The Ritz-
Carlton, sharing all of the services of the hotel.

From 2001 to 2007, Boston was home to two Ritz-Carlton hotels that faced each
other across Boston Common. The Ritz-Carlton, Boston Common opened in 2001.

In November 2006, [Taj Hotels](/wiki/Taj_Hotels "Taj Hotels"), a subsidiary of
the India-based [Tata Group](/wiki/Tata_Group "Tata Group"), purchased The
Ritz-Carlton Boston from its owners, Millennium Partners for $170 million. The
Ritz-Carlton Boston became the _Taj Boston_ on January 11, 2007.[16]

## The Ritz-Carlton today[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Ritz-
Carlton_Hotel_Company&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: The Ritz-Carlton
today")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Mosque_and_The_Ritz-
Carlton_Hotel.JPG/170px-Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Mosque_and_The_Ritz-
Carlton_Hotel.JPG)](/wiki/File:Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Mosque_and_The_Ritz-
Carlton_Hotel.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Mosque_and_The_Ritz-Carlton_Hotel.JPG "Enlarge")

The Ritz-Carlton Hotel, [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul"), from the
[Bosphorus](/wiki/Bosphorus "Bosphorus")

The company grew under the leadership of President and COO Horst Schulze.
Schulze instituted a company-wide concentration on both the personal and the
data-driven sides of service: He coined the company's well-known
customer/employee-centered motto, "We are Ladies and Gentlemen Serving Ladies
and Gentlemen" and the set of specific service values (standards) on which The
Ritz-Carlton employees base service through the present day.[17] Under his
leadership the hotels earned an unprecedented two [Malcolm Baldrige National
Quality Awards](/wiki/Malcolm_Baldrige_National_Quality_Award "Malcolm
Baldrige National Quality Award")[18] and grew from four to forty U.S.
locations.[19]

During this time, The Ritz-Carlton also became known for its influence on
service in a wide range of industries, through the creation of The Ritz-
Carlton Learning Institute and [The Ritz-Carlton Leadership
Center](https://web.archive.org/web/20130427190238/http://corporate.ritzcarlton.com/en/LeadershipCenter/Default.htm),
created by then-Ritz executive Leonardo Inghilleri, who was an architect of
the Ritz's second Baldrige award, where executives from other companies
worldwide in many disciplines come to learn The Ritz-Carlton principles of
service.[20]

In 1995, Marriott International purchased a 49% stake in The Ritz-Carlton
Hotel Company, and in 1998, they purchased an additional 50% stake in the
company, giving it 99% ownership of the company. Schulze and other executives
(including Leonardo Inghilleri, Robert A. Warman and Peter Schoch) left to
form the West Paces Hotel Group, which took the name of its primary brand,
Capella Hotels, in December 2011.[21] In 2007, the partners also formed Solís
Hotels.[22]

The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company is now headquartered in [Chevy Chase,
Maryland](/wiki/Chevy_Chase,_Maryland "Chevy Chase, Maryland"), located in the
[Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.")
[MSA](/wiki/Metropolitan_Statistical_Area "Metropolitan Statistical Area").

The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company partnered with [Bulgari](/wiki/Bulgari
"Bulgari") in 2001 to operate a chain of hotels owned by and operated under
the BVLGARI brand. The company currently has marketing agreements with
[Bulgari Hotels & Resorts](/wiki/Bulgari "Bulgari"), the [Cosmopolitan of Las
Vegas](/wiki/Cosmopolitan_of_Las_Vegas "Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas"), the
privately owned [Ritz-Carlton Montreal](/wiki/Ritz-Carlton_Montreal "Ritz-
Carlton Montreal"), [The Ritz Hotel London](/wiki/The_Ritz_Hotel_London "The
Ritz Hotel London") and the [Hotel Ritz Madrid](/wiki/Ritz_Hotel,_Madrid "Ritz
Hotel, Madrid").

In 2011, The Ritz-Carlton, Hong Kong was opened. It is the tallest hotel in
the world.

Simon Cooper joined Ritz-Carlton in 2001 as President and [Chief Operating
Officer](/wiki/Chief_Operating_Officer "Chief Operating Officer"), taking the
helm from Horst Schulze. Cooper's mandate was to grow the chain through hotel
expansion and product diversification. Under Cooper's watch the company has
aggressively expanded its hotels and added The Ritz-Carlton Residences,
private residential units, and The Ritz-Carlton Destination Club, fractional
ownership residences, to the company's development program.

August 12, 2010, Ritz-Carlton announced its new President and Chief Operations
Officer would be Herve Humler, one of the founders of the 1983 company, who
will be responsible for leading brand operations and global growth
strategy.[23] In 2015, The Ritz-Carlton, Macau was opened. It is located at
the Galaxy Macau. The Ritz-Carlton, Macau is designed as a gold palace.

### Awards[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Ritz-
Carlton_Hotel_Company&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Awards")]

The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company has been featured on [Zagat
Survey](/wiki/Zagat_Survey "Zagat Survey") Top Lists for dining, hotels and
service. The [Dallas, USA](/wiki/Dallas,_USA "Dallas, USA") and [Wolfsburg,
Germany](/wiki/Wolfsburg,_Germany "Wolfsburg, Germany") locations both
received top honors from Zagat in 2009, including Top Large Hotel for the
Dallas location.[24] The Ritz-Carlton is the only company to date to win two
[Malcolm Baldrige National Quality
Awards](/wiki/Malcolm_Baldrige_National_Quality_Award "Malcolm Baldrige
National Quality Award") (1992 and 1999). Ritz-Carlton's President and COO
Horst Schulze was recognized for Ritz-Carlton's contributions during his
tenure with Corporate Hotelier of the World Ishikawa Medal for contributions
to the Quality movement.[25]

### Other accomplishments[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Ritz-
Carlton_Hotel_Company&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Other
accomplishments")]

The Ritz-Carlton is notable for attempting to share its knowledge of quality
as it applies to service. Initially this was done at the request of the
Baldrige committee, but The Ritz-Carlton ultimately adopted this as a central
mission through the creation of The Ritz-Carlton Learning Institute and The
Ritz-Carlton Leadership Center.[20]

In October, 2011, [Angella Reid](/wiki/Angella_Reid "Angella Reid"), the
General Manager of The Ritz-Carlton Hotel in [Pentagon
City](/wiki/Pentagon_City "Pentagon City"), [Virginia](/wiki/Virginia
"Virginia") was appointed as [White House Chief
Usher](/wiki/White_House_Chief_Usher "White House Chief Usher"), becoming the
first woman to serve in that post.[26]

It also has major service training operations in its Ritz-Carlton Learning
Institute and Ritz-Carlton Leadership Center, created by Ritz-Carlton
executive _(emeritus)_ Leonardo Inghilleri,[20] where nearly 50,000[19]
executives from other companies worldwide have been trained in The Ritz-
Carlton principles of service.

### Notable current properties[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Ritz-
Carlton_Hotel_Company&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Notable current
properties")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/2014_Moskva_Ritz-
Carlton_building.JPG/220px-2014_Moskva_Ritz-
Carlton_building.JPG)](/wiki/File:2014_Moskva_Ritz-Carlton_building.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:2014_Moskva_Ritz-Carlton_building.JPG "Enlarge")

The Ritz-Carlton, located in [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow "Moscow")

In 1999 Ritz-Carlton acquired the former [Hotel St.
Moritz](/wiki/Hotel_St._Moritz "Hotel St. Moritz") in [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), reestablishing a presence in New
York for the first time since the 1951 demolition of their previous
building.[27]

Actually, a Ritz-Carlton opened in Manhattan, New York City, in 1982 or 1983.
See "NEW RITZ-CARLTON OFFERS LUXURY ON SMALLER SCALE," New York Times, April
25, 1982. <https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/25/nyregion/new-ritz-carlton-
offers-luxury-on-smaller-scale.html>

The first Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Russia, The [Moscow Ritz-
Carlton](/w/index.php?title=Moscow_Ritz-Carlton&action=edit&redlink=1 "Moscow
Ritz-Carlton \(page does not exist\)")
([ru](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%A2%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%83%D0%BB%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B0_\(%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0\)
"ru:Тверская улица \(Москва\)")), opened 1 July 2007 on [Tverskaya
Street](/wiki/Tverskaya_Street "Tverskaya Street"). The Ritz-Carlton Suite,
billed at [US$](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar")13,715 per
night, is listed at number 13 on _World 's 15 most expensive hotel suites_
compiled by [CNN](/wiki/CNN "CNN") in 2012.[28]

In 2014, Oberoi Realty and Ritz-Carlton announced they would construct a hotel
in Mumbai with an expected opening in 2016. Ritz-Carlton opened its first
Indian property in Bangalore in 2013.[29]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/International_Commerce_Centre_201008.jpg/170px-
International_Commerce_Centre_201008.jpg)](/wiki/File:International_Commerce_Centre_201008.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:International_Commerce_Centre_201008.jpg "Enlarge")

[The Ritz-Carlton, Hong Kong](/wiki/The_Ritz-Carlton,_Hong_Kong "The Ritz-
Carlton, Hong Kong") occupies floors 102 to 108 of the [International Commerce
Centre](/wiki/International_Commerce_Centre "International Commerce Centre")

On 29 March 2011, The Ritz-Carlton opened the highest hotel in the world, [The
Ritz-Carlton, Hong Kong](/wiki/The_Ritz-Carlton,_Hong_Kong "The Ritz-Carlton,
Hong Kong") on floors 102-108 of the [International Commerce
Centre](/wiki/International_Commerce_Centre "International Commerce Centre")
in [Tsim Sha Tsui](/wiki/Tsim_Sha_Tsui "Tsim Sha Tsui") on Kowloon Peninsula,
Hong Kong.[30] The lobby is 425 m (1,394 ft) above the ground, making the
hotel the tallest in Asia.[31] Asian Headquarters of Morgan Stanley, Credit
Suisse, and Deutsche Bank are located in the same 110-storey building.[32]

The Ritz-Carlton, Charlotte which opened in October 2009 is the first Ritz-
Carlton property to earn LEED Gold Certification[33] and the youngest Ritz-
Carlton property to earn five-diamonds, and is the only five diamond property
in Charlotte (and one of only three in the state of [North
Carolina](/wiki/North_Carolina "North Carolina")).

The Ritz-Carlton, Fort Lauderdale (AAA Five Diamond Award) which opened in
August 2008 opened as a St. Regis just one year prior.

The Ritz-Carlton and [JW Marriott Hotels](/wiki/JW_Marriott_Hotels "JW
Marriott Hotels") at [L.A. Live](/wiki/L.A._Live "L.A. Live") opened February
2010 and share the first skyscraper built since the early 1990s in [Downtown
Los Angeles](/wiki/Downtown_Los_Angeles "Downtown Los Angeles"). The Ritz-
Carlton, Los Angeles was awarded a [LEED silver
certification](/wiki/Leadership_in_Energy_and_Environmental_Design "Leadership
in Energy and Environmental Design").[34]

The readers of [Condé Nast Traveler](/wiki/Cond%C3%A9_Nast_Traveler "Condé
Nast Traveler") elected The Ritz-Carlton Shanghai, Pudong as "The Best Hotel
in Asia" from 2012 through 2014.[35]

The Ritz-Carlton operates fractional residences at several locations in the
United States under the name Ritz-Carlton Destination Club. Properties include
Aspen Highlands and Vail in [Colorado](/wiki/Colorado "Colorado"), [St.
Thomas](/wiki/Saint_Thomas,_U.S._Virgin_Islands "Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin
Islands") in the [U.S. Virgin Islands](/wiki/U.S._Virgin_Islands "U.S. Virgin
Islands"), [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco") and [Jupiter,
Florida](/wiki/Jupiter,_Florida "Jupiter, Florida").

On Tuesday 17 July 2009, at 7:47 a.m. Jakarta time, a [bomb
exploded](/wiki/2009_Jakarta_bombings "2009 Jakarta bombings") in The Ritz-
Carlton Mega Kuningan, [Jakarta](/wiki/Jakarta "Jakarta"),
[Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia "Indonesia") destroying the first floor of the
hotel. The explosion occurred 2 minutes after the explosion at the nearby [JW
Marriott Jakarta](/wiki/JW_Marriott_Jakarta "JW Marriott Jakarta"). The hotel
was scheduled to host the [Manchester United](/wiki/Manchester_United
"Manchester United") football club the following Monday during the Indonesia
leg of its Asia tour, but the visit was canceled due to the bombing.[36] Nine
people including 2 suicide bombers were killed.[37]

On 26 August 2013, members of the [Filipino diaspora](/wiki/Filipino_diaspora
"Filipino diaspora") protested at The Ritz-Carlton, Los Angeles and JW
Marriott Hotels at L.A. Live against the [Priority Development Assistance Fund
scam](/wiki/Priority_Development_Assistance_Fund_scam "Priority Development
Assistance Fund scam"). It is believed that the family of the alleged
mastermind of the scam [Janet Lim-Napoles](/wiki/Janet_Lim-Napoles "Janet Lim-
Napoles") owned a condominium unit in the building said to be worth $2
million.[38]

On 31 October 2013, The Ritz-Carlton Bangalore is opened and the first
property in India.[39]

On 4 November 2013, the Ritz-Carlton Kazakhstan opened in
[Almaty](/wiki/Almaty "Almaty"). The 145-room hotel sits on the top floors of
the Esentai Tower, the tallest building in Central Asia. The upper floors also
include the Ritz-Carlton Residences as well. The hotel includes a steakhouse,
a sky bar, a business center, spa and 9,000 square metres (97,000 sq ft) of
meeting space. The rooms include in-room safes, power outlets for laptops,
iPod docking stations and marble bathrooms.[40][41]

In January 2014, Ritz-Carlton opened a hotel in [Herzliya](/wiki/Herzliya
"Herzliya"), [Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel") featuring a spa and the brand's
first kosher restaurant.[42]

The [Ritz-Carlton Kuala Lumpur](/wiki/Ritz-Carlton_Kuala_Lumpur "Ritz-Carlton
Kuala Lumpur") in Malaysia's capital city, opened in 1997, is the only 'all
butler hotel' operating in the city, offering butler service to all of its
300+ rooms and suites and has since been ranked among the "Gold List" of
hotels by Condé Nast, ranked as "one of the top five butler hotels" by The
Independent and regarded by Travel and Leisure as one of "The World's Greatest
Hotels".[43]

In [E.B. White](/wiki/E.B._White "E.B. White")'s children's novel _[The
Trumpet of the Swan](/wiki/The_Trumpet_of_the_Swan "The Trumpet of the Swan")_
, the main character Louis (a [trumpeter swan](/wiki/Trumpeter_swan "Trumpeter
swan")) stays at the Ritz-Carlton Boston, where he eats watercress sandwiches
and sleeps in the bathtub.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Ritz-
Carlton_in_Half_Moon_Bay%2C_California.jpg/220px-Ritz-
Carlton_in_Half_Moon_Bay%2C_California.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ritz-
Carlton_in_Half_Moon_Bay,_California.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ritz-Carlton_in_Half_Moon_Bay,_California.jpg "Enlarge")

Ritz-Carlton in Half Moon Bay, California

On the [HBO](/wiki/HBO "HBO") original series _[Boardwalk
Empire](/wiki/Boardwalk_Empire "Boardwalk Empire")_ , the character of Enoch
"Nucky" Thompson (portrayed by [Steve Buscemi](/wiki/Steve_Buscemi "Steve
Buscemi")), the treasurer of [Atlantic
County](/wiki/Atlantic_County,_New_Jersey "Atlantic County, New Jersey"),
occupies the entire 9th floor of a fictionalized version of the hotel in
[Atlantic City, New Jersey](/wiki/Atlantic_City,_New_Jersey "Atlantic City,
New Jersey"). The real [Enoch "Nucky" Johnson](/wiki/Enoch_L._Johnson "Enoch
L. Johnson") on which Nucky Thompson was based did in fact occupy an entire
floor of suites at the [Ritz-Carlton Atlantic City](/wiki/Ritz-
Carlton_Atlantic_City "Ritz-Carlton Atlantic City") until his arrest in 1941
on charges of [tax evasion](/wiki/Tax_evasion "Tax evasion").

A 1922 short story by [F. Scott Fitzgerald](/wiki/F._Scott_Fitzgerald "F.
Scott Fitzgerald") is titled, "[The Diamond as Big as the
Ritz](/wiki/The_Diamond_as_Big_as_the_Ritz "The Diamond as Big as the Ritz")."

The 2003 movie, [American Wedding](/wiki/American_Wedding "American Wedding")
used the Ritz-Carlton in [Half Moon Bay,
California](/wiki/Half_Moon_Bay,_California "Half Moon Bay, California"), as
the filming location for the wedding venue.

The Ritz also features in the [Irving Berlin](/wiki/Irving_Berlin "Irving
Berlin") song "[Puttin' On the Ritz](/wiki/Puttin%27_On_the_Ritz "Puttin' On
the Ritz")" in which the hotel chain served as an inspiration for the titular
expression, meaning to live opulently

In 2015, the rapper [Plies](/wiki/Plies_\(rapper\) "Plies \(rapper\)")
released the song "Ritz Carlton". In the song, he raps about his affinity for
routinely spending time at the lavish hotel. He also boasts about a prior
situation where he "ran off on the plug twice".

The Ritz Paris was also referenced in Kenneth Oppel's novel
_[Skybreaker](/wiki/Skybreaker "Skybreaker")_. The main character visits for a
meeting with a man who wants the coordinates of the mythical airship
_Hyperion_. The man he meets mentions that he enjoyed "putting on the Ritz",
but would be foolish to pay for it.

[Michael Hutchence](/wiki/Michael_Hutchence "Michael Hutchence") of
[INXS](/wiki/INXS "INXS") aged 37 was found dead at the [Ritz-
Carlton](/wiki/Ritz-Carlton "Ritz-Carlton") hotel in Double Bay,
[Sydney](/wiki/Sydney "Sydney") on 22 November 1997 in Room 524

American telenovela and drama _[Jane the Virgin](/wiki/Jane_the_Virgin "Jane
the Virgin")_ , aired on [The CW](/wiki/The_CW "The CW"), uses the Ritz-
Carlton Marina Del Rey's property as the setting for the show, while the
storyline is based in Miami (whereas that Ritz-Carlton Marina Del Ray is in
[Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles"), California).
